node.title: Australia is preparing for COVID-19 vaccines for young children â€” but how urgent is the need?
node.alt: A young boy wearing glasses and a mask looks at the camera as he is vaccinated
node.description: As state leaders push for all children to be vaccinated by the year's end, National Cabinet mulls vaccines for younger kids. But the regulator is still waiting for details on safety and efficacy.
node.content:
["As children in the United States begin to get their first COVID-19 vaccinations, Australia's leaders will be discussing vaccinating Australian kids.", "The premiers, chief ministers and Prime Minister will be coming together today for their regular National Cabinet meeting to discuss issues related to the pandemic.", "Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has flagged that he wants to talk about plans for vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds.", "\"The FDA [US Food and Drug Administration] and the [Joe] Biden administration have not only got approval but have ordered literally tens of millions of these doses, hopefully our federal government is doing the same,\" he said yesterday.", "\"It would be great to think we could make a dent into that before the school year ended.\"", "But just how urgent is the need for vaccines for kids under 12?", "
Time for a discussion
", "", "
Dr\u00a0Sarah McNab says, in rare cases, primary school aged children have been admitted to hospital with COVID-19.(Supplied)
", "Dr. Sarah McNab, head of general medicine at the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne, says it's the right time for leaders to be discussing the issue.", "\"It's good to be thinking about vaccines for children, in very rare cases we've seen children of primary school age become sicker with COVID-19 and need to come into hospital,\" Dr McNab said.", "Pfizer has started an application to Australia's medicines regulator, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).", "The Australian Technical Advisory Group (ATAGI) will also need to make its own assessment before any vaccine is rolled out to kids.", "Dr. McNab said those organisations would be taking a very close look at the vaccine.", "\"It's really important that we consider both the potential benefits of the vaccination and also make sure it's a vaccine that's safe for children,\" she said.", "\"It's great that we're having these discussions now and having them early while the TGA is looking at the data.\"", "
Kids key in transmission
", "While the majority of children who contract COVID-19 only experience very mild symptoms, Dr McNab points out there are strong reasons to have a vaccine for under-12s.", "\"We have seen schools being closed because of COVID outbreaks and I think reducing that indirect harm is really important, if we can.", "\"If we have a safe vaccine for children I will absolutely be vaccinating my own children and be encouraging other people to do so.\"", "The director of the National Centre for Immunisation Research and Surveillance, Professor Kristine Macartney, says there are a number of factors to consider.", "", "
Paediatrician Kristine Macartney says Australian authorities can observe data from the US.(News Video)
", "\"There is a bit of a need to look with the crystal ball and understand how much COVID-19 will circulate in children and what the modelling studies predict,\" Professor Macartney said.", "\"We're obviously needing to consider factors of transmission.\"", "Being able to observe data from the US would be useful to Australian authorities, she said.", "\"We'll know a lot more about any potential long-term side effects that are rare, often mild, but rare.\"", "\"There is a vaccine that is potentially available, but as [parents] would expect it's being looked at really closely as to whether it's the right decision for Australia.\""]
